section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to listen as you say the word hat. Together name words that rhyme with hat.
section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Hh and Qq Alphabet Cards.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to sing the song “I Like to Eat Apples and Bananas.” Add: “I like to eat, eat, eat munchy, crunchy apples. I like to eat, eat, eat tasty, sweet bananas.“

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Little Nita’s Big Idea, written by Anna W. Bardaus and illustrated by Carolina Farias.
Pablo loves all sorts of narratives, but he especially loves stories about sharing!
Here is a question that we can think about as we listen to the story. Then we’ll talk about it.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the neighbors help Nita?

section.rac_body-text: Read the book aloud and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What was Nita’s big idea? Show me with your arms how big you think she wants her fruit salad to be.
A neighbor calls Nita chiquita, which means “little one” in Spanish. Let’s say the Spanish word chiquita.
Nita smells the mango. It has a sweet scent. Besides smelling sweet, what else do you notice about the mango?
What fruits do people share?
Look at all that fruit! Pretend you’re tasting the fruit. How does it taste? What is in this salad that makes it a healthy snack for everyone?

section.rac_body-text: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do the neighbors help Nita?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences that tell about Nita’s fruit salad.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does one girl give Nita?
One girl gives Nita a b______ (banana).
One girl gives Nita a banana.
Which fruits do you think are the best for fruit salad? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Many languages, such as English, Spanish, and French, are alphabet languages. To be able to read, children must understand that the system of letters stands for a series of sounds. Children who can recognize letters with accuracy will find it easier to understand the sounds linked to the letters.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’s CREATE | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make Plans
section-block.rac_body-text: Begin a discussion about making plans. Say: If you make plans to get ready for school, what steps do you have to take to reach that goal and be ready for school? What if your family plans a party? What would they have to do?
Explain that when we make plans, we decide what we want to do and then we figure how to do it.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to talk about the Mind Builder and see how Little Nita makes plans as we revisit the book Little Nita’s Big Idea, written by Anna W. Bardaus and illustrated by Carolina Farias.
Clifford knows that making plans helps us reach a goal. He likes to read narratives about plans and reaching goals.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about how Nita makes a plan to reach her goal—to make the biggest fruit salad in the world!
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.
Why do you think making the world’s biggest fruit salad sounds like lots of fun? (MB)
Nita plans to have her neighbors help her, but they cannot. Show me with your face how you think she feels when no one can help her. (MB)
Since no one could help her, Nita decides to bring her mango and big bowl to the square. Who is the first person to help now? (MB)
How do you think Nita feels when she sees everyone working together to help her? How do you know?
Look at that delicious fruit salad! Pretend to eat it. Rub your belly and say,”Yum! Yum!” Why was Nita able to make her plan work? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Guide children to make plans for making a fruit salad. Talk about the steps they might include:
1. Add the cut-up fruits to a bowl.
2. Mix the fruits together.
3. Use a spoon and put some on your plate.
4. Eat the fruit salad.

Then assign the children to groups of four. Have each group act out the steps in the plan, encouraging each child to show one of the steps. Ask children how they would feel if they had really made the fruit salad as they planned.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how Nita plans to make the biggest fruit salad in the whole world.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Often we need to help children understand that a goal can be reached “one step at a time.” Look for opportunities for children to set a goal that they can reach in a short amount of time, such as completing a picture for a class display. Note the steps that they followed and talk about how they felt when they reached the goal. (Parents.com/Goal Setting)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’s CREATE | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Present children with several fruits, or use the Activity Cards that show them. Name and talk about why fruits are a healthy, nutritious snack or part of a meal.
Invite children to clap syllables with you. Begin with ap-ple and ba-nan-a. Each time, ask children how many claps they use. Continue with words that name fruits.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Little Nita’s Big Idea, written by Anna W. Bardaus and illustrated by Carolina Farias.
Pablo loves this narrative because Nita has such big ideas!
This is the guiding question I want you to think about:
What is special about Nita’s fruit salad?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is different about Nita’s idea for a fruit salad? Do you think it’s a good idea?
Nita asks, “Wouldn’t it be even more delicious with a banana?” Who answers her question? Do you agree with Nita?
Neighbors bring papayas, persimmons, grapes, and apples. What do you notice about the size of the fruits?
Everyone peeled and cut the fruit. Show me how you peel a ripe orange that’s ready to eat.
Who can point to the orange? If you saw more than one orange, what would you call them?

Look at the boy with the carrots. When you make a smart guess about what’s going to happen later, you make a prediction. Let’s make a smart guess about what Nita will want to do next. Did you guess she will want to make the biggest vegetable soup?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What is special about Nita’s fruit salad?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Lots of people helped make it.
It had many kinds of fruit.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to retell one part of this story.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is special about the size of Nita’s fruit salad?
What very big thing would you like to make? How would you make it?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Some children may not be familiar with some of the fruits described in the story. Suggest to family members that when children are afraid to try new foods, having adults eat the “new” food with them is very helpful. Encourage them to talk about the flavor and texture of the foods they share.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S CREATE | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Have a discussion with children about folktales. Say: Children love to listen to stories. Some stories have animal characters. Sometimes the animals talk just like people do. Have you ever heard the story of The Three Little Pigs? Have you ever heard the story of The Three Bears? Those are old tales that children love hearing again and again. Clap three times if you love to listen to old tales like those!

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Voice in Rabbit’s House. We will read an old tale on this poster.
Pablo the Parrot loves to hear a good folktale. The animal characters act just like people!
Little Nita’s Big Idea and The Voice in Rabbit’s House each tell a story.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What stories do we like to tell?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Telling a Tale
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where is the caterpillar going? Does it look scary or not so scary?
Why does Rabbit “tremble in fear”? Show me what Rabbit looks like when he “trembles in fear.”
Who is bigger, Leopard or Rabbit? What does Leopard do that Rabbit did?
Who is bigger, Rhinoceros or Leopard? Why is Rhinoceros scared?
What is Frog’s plan to help his friends? Turn to your neighbor and say, “I can help.” (MB)
How did the animals feel at the end of the story? Were you surprised and laughing, too?
Both Nita and Caterpillar had good ideas. What were they?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Little Nita’s Big Idea book cover.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out the story. Ask them to use a very big voice and say, “I am the The Long Furry One.” Then say, Be Rabbit and show me how you tremble. Next, have children repeat, “I am the The Long Furry One.” Then say, Be Leopard and show me how you tremble. Continue to the end of the story.
Provide a writing prompt about what Frog did and guide children’s responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Multilingual learners will benefit from stories that use repeating language. Take this opportunity to have children say the repeating parts of the story with you to help them gain confidence using language. Make sure they understand the meaning of each sentence.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’s CREATE | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to tell one part of the story they liked. Encourage children to explain why they liked that part of the story. How did it make them feel?
Invite children to tell if they like to eat the fruits in the story. Call out fruits. Have children give a thumbs- up or thumbs-down to show how they feel.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’ll retell and reenact the story Little Nita’s Big Idea by Anna W. Bardaus.
Pablo likes this narrative because he likes reading about neighbors being friendly!
This week we read all about Nita and her neighbors. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
If you were Nita’s neighbor, what would you do?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the story together. Use Equity Sticks to have children actively participate in the discussion.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we are busy neighbors. Let’s be busy making a pizza. Let’s be busy riding a bike. Let’s be busy helping people cross the street.
Let’s say the word neighbor and and clap the parts: neigh-bor. Two parts!
Nita doesn’t want to give up when her neighbors can’t help. Can you think of a time you didn’t want to give up? What did you do?
Now Nita says the salad would be marvelous with an orange. What would you say is marvelous about an orange?
Let’s stand up and slowly carry a big, big, delicious orange. Be careful! It’s really big! Now let’s peel the big orange.
How are the neighbors helping Nita? Why did they change their minds about helping? Have you ever helped a neighbor? How did you feel?
This is the world’s biggest fruit salad, so let’s take out our cameras and take some marvelous pictures of it. Click! Click! Click!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Invite children to share their ideas about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: If you were Nita’s neighbor, what would you do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share ideas.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would help to mix the fruit.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about the part of this story they like best. Have them share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How would you help Nita if you were her neighbor?
What will Nita need to make vegetable soup?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When children make personal connections to characters in a story, they understand the main ideas and themes more deeply. Help children explain personal experiences that help them make connections to the characters and events in the story.
